message.content:
Step 1: Compute the Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio.
• From the cash flow statement, the Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities is –64,099.10.
• From the income statement, the Net Profit is 707,199.17.
• Ratio = (–64,099.10) / (707,199.17) ≈ –0.09065, which we round to –0.09.

Step 2: Compute the Current Assets Turnover Ratio.
• The formula is Total Revenue ÷ Average Current Assets.
• Total Revenue from the income statement is 5,064,939.23.
• Average Current Assets = (Beginning Total Current Assets + Ending Total Current Assets) / 2 
  = (8,000,000.00 + 9,717,259.46) / 2 ≈ 8,858,629.73.
• Ratio = 5,064,939.23 ÷ 8,858,629.73 ≈ 0.5717, which rounds to 0.57.

Step 3: Compute the Quick Ratio.
• The Quick Ratio = (Cash and Cash Equivalents + Accounts Receivable + Interest Receivable) ÷ Total Current Liabilities.
• Using end-of-period values:
  Cash on Hand = 4,540,900.90  
  Bank Deposits = 2,866,063.83  
  Interest Receivable = 8,967.44  
  Accounts Receivable = 1,851,327.29  
  Quick Assets = 4,540,900.90 + 2,866,063.83 + 8,967.44 + 1,851,327.29 ≈ 9,267,259.46.
• Total Current Liabilities = 1,493,246.99.
• Quick Ratio = 9,267,259.46 ÷ 1,493,246.99 ≈ 6.206, which rounds to 6.21.

Thus, the final answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio": "-0.09",
    "Current Assets Turnover Ratio": "0.57",
    "Quick Ratio": "6.21"
  }
}
